Joseph is a 27-year-old hardworking  married man, who adds additional income to support his family. His wife and him are blessed with two children. Joseph has been a taxi driver for a period of six years earning himself an income of KES 10,000 at the end of every month.
 
Joseph is now servicing his second loan of KES. 45,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use this amount to buy new tires to replace the old ones, which are worn out.

Joseph plans to use the anticipated income to pay school fees for his children and hopes to have a bright future with a successful life.

loans.use: To buy new tires and replace the old tires which are worn out

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cows and goats to add to the plantation

loans.name: Beneditor

texts.en:
Beneditor is 37 years old. He is married to Rose, and together they have been blessed with five children between the ages of two and thirteen. Rose provides additional income for her family.

Beneditor is a poultry farmer. He has been in this business for the last 13 years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000. 

Beneditor has requested his third loan from VisionFund Kenya of KES 45,000, which he will use to add stock of poultry for sale.

With the anticipated profits, Beneditor will be able to pay school fees for his children. His hope and dream for the future is to have a stable source of income and business, which will ensure his children are educated for life. He also desires to see his business expand to other locations.

loans.use: to buy more stock of poultry

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en:
Priscilla, 71, is an experienced farmer based in Kamagut village in the North Rift region of Kenya. She lives with the father of her 4 children; she has been married to him for more than half a century! 

The couple owns 9 acres of fertile land located near a river where she fetches water. On the farm, she has 2 cows, 5 head of poultry and sheep. Despite her age, the spirit she has for growing her business to greater heights is still alive and well. Priscilla is seeking a loan to purchase an additional dairy cow. This is in a bid to increase the volume of the milk produced for sale. 

Priscilla stands to increase her income significantly once the new cow becomes productive. She will use the income from this investment to support her children and their children.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en: Agatha is 34 years old and married with five children living in Kasese, Uganda. For 13 years, Agatha has been selling second hand clothes to look after her children. Agatha is a hardworking woman with a dream of expanding her business and educating her children to university despite the challenge of inadequate capital to stock what her customers are demanding. Agatha wants money to buy second-hand clothes for selling.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba is a maize farmer from Bawa Rumi village in Kaduna State, Nigeria. 

Before joining Babban Gona member, Habiba had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs (for food, clothes...).

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Habiba can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later at prices up to 40% higher than the market prices at harvest. Habiba, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to be one of the most profitable farmers in her community.

loans.use: To pay for ugent expenses (food, clothing...), and store her maize harvest to sell it later at higher prices

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with three kids, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Ali operates a vegetable selling stall. He sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. He faces a challenge in the high cost of transportation to his place of operation. He dreams of expanding and establishing a motorcycle transport business in the future. 

With the KES 40,000 he wants to purchase green vegetables, two crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, two crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kabale in the Kabale region of Uganda. He is married and has four children with two of them currently in school. For the past four years, Wilson has been working hard to manage his food store, which sells Irish potatoes.

To help expand his business, Wilson has requested a loan of UGX 2,000,000 from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of Irish potatoes, and will help Wilson to generate greater profits and expand the business. Wilson hopes that in the future he will be able to expand the business more. 

Wilson is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Wilson who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of Irish potatoes

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en:
Abdallah is 40 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children with 2 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Abdallah has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells posho, maize flour, beans, sugar, rice, bread, curry powder, salt, bread, and soap. 

To help expand his business, Abdallah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy posho, maize flour, beans, sugar, rice, bread,  curry powder, salt, bread and soap.  The loan will help Abdallah to generate greater profits and boost his business. 

Abdallah hopes that in the future he will be able to improve his family's standard of living. 

Abdallah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Abdallah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy posho, maize flour, beans, sugar, rice, bread, curry powder, salt, bread, and soap.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Ruth, a 42-year-old mother who is very kind, loving, and charming. She is based in Kapomboi, a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. She is happily married and has five children that depend on her for the basic needs. For the past sixteen years, she has been involved in mixed farming on her small piece of land. Her major primary sources of income are milk, egg selling, crops, and some personal business she engages in to make ends meet. She passionately loves poultry farming, and when asked what is most enjoyable about poultry farming, her response was “feeding my poultry.” 

She sells eggs and poultry products to her neighbors and to the local market, and, because of high quality eggs, customers have been streaming into her compound, and the demand has been overwhelming. To be able to meet the demand, she is requesting a loan to buy additional poultry. Through the loan, she will buy quality breeds of poultry that have high productivity, and hence, satisfy the demand that is there. The increased income level will be used in improving her living conditions, and she plans on expanding her business to other towns. Other than increased profits, she will also benefit from poultry manure, which will be used in her vegetable garden to increase productivity. Increased profits will make her business flourish, and hence, provide a secure solid education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase quality poultry for her farm

loans.name: Hakim

texts.en:
Hakim is 25 years old and lives in the town of Kinobi in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married. and has no children. For the past 3 years, Hakim has been working hard to manage his electronics business, which sells electronics items. 

To help expand his business, Hakim has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more electronics, and will help Hakim to generate greater profits and construct rental houses. Hakim hopes that in the future he will be able to expand into a wholesale shop. 

Hakim is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Hakim who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more electronics

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is 50 years old and lives in the town of Kigumba in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, William has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells juice, body moisturizer, books, sugar and oil. 

To help expand his business, William has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy juice, books, sugar and oil, and will help William to generate greater profits and improve his standards of living. William hopes that in the future he will be able to buy a maize milling machine. 

William is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like William who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy juice, Vaseline, books, sugar and oil

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 54 years old. She is widowed and blessed with one child who is 22 years old. 

Alice sells clothes as well as owns rental apartments, businesses she has done for the last ten years. She earns a monthly income of KES 48,000. 

She has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya of KES 20,000. She will use the loan to renovate her rental houses in order to make them more appealing so as to sustain her tenants. 

With the anticipated profits, Alice will be able to add stock of clothes for her clothing business. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to have a stable business through which her family can be sustainably provided for.

loans.use: to renovate her rental houses.

loans.name: Vesna

texts.en:
Vesna wants to thank all of the lenders who helped her renovate her house. Before her first loan, her toilet was outside the house, which made things very difficult, especially in bad weather conditions. 

Now she has a bathroom inside her home, thanks to the lenders. She is requesting a second loan to renovate the inside toilet.This improvement is very much appreciated and will make life much easier and more comfortable. Although her husband still works doing manual labor as a helper, she is still searching for a job.

loans.use: To renovate her bathroom

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: This is Caroline, a mother of two children and a farmer. Over the years, she has enjoyed a a steady income from dairy farming. She is able to pay school fees for her children and take care of her other expenses. Her passion is in rearing cows especially dairy cows and she hopes to expand her her dairy farming to increase her income. With a Kiva loan, she will be able to buy an additional cow

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Hala

texts.en:
Hala is a 46-year-old married mother of three children. Due to the low financial situation of her husband, she decided three years ago to start selling accessories and shoes to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family.

Hala is a talented saleswoman who has a good marketing skills, as she has a good reputation among her customers. Today, Hala is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with more requested products to satisfy her customers' needs and to attract new ones.

Hala hopes to open her own accessories shop in the future to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with more requested products

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel is a married man. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a farm where he grows tea. His business is located in a rural area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be changes in weather conditions, which affect his tea crops. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy farm inputs. His business goal is to excel within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will be successful. He will use the anticipated profits to buy more farm inputs.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Jemimah

texts.en:
Jemimah is 33 years old, married and together with her spouse they have been blessed with two children. She has a water supply business which she has been running for the past four years.

She plans to use this loan to buy water cans to use in supplying water and this will enable her to serve more customers. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

This is her third loan term from VisionFund Kenya and she paid her previous loans well. Her future hopes are to grow her business and be successful, make more income and educate her children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: to buy more stock of water cans to supply water.

loans.name: Polline

texts.en:
Polline is 32 years old. She is married and together with her husband they have been blessed with three children, who are 12, 10 and 6 years old.

Polline is a farmer, a business she has had for the last four years, earning a monthly income of Kshs. 20,000. 

She has requested her first loan with VisionFund Kenya for Kshs. 10,000, which she will use to add farm inputs like fertilizers and seedlings, and pay laborers.

With the anticipated profits, Polline will be able to pay school fees for her children as well as repay her loan. Her hope and dream for the future is to have a stable business through which she can provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and seedlings, and pay laborers.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be ambitious. 

She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a busy area, and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poor sales. 

She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. 

Her business goal is to be a wholesale distributor within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be self-reliant. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for a posho mill.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is a married man with one child. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.

Andrew wants to start a business selling vegetables and fruits. His major goal is to become a leading fruit vendor in the area to raise his profits. For that reason, he wants to purchase with the 30,000 KES loan green vegetables and sacks of fruits, such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaw. He decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits, such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaw

loans.name: Advije

texts.en:
Advije wants to thank all of the lenders for her first loan, which she used to open a hair salon in her house. She has been working a lot since she opened and continues to be satisfied with her business. 

She is requesting a second loan to purchase newer and updated tools and materials for her work. In this way, she will ensure that she can provide the best quality for her customers and attract new ones. She has five children and wants to have another baby, so she is hopeful to make her business big enough to provide for a large family. She appreciates all the Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase tools and materials.

loans.name: Jasemine

texts.en:
Jasemine wants to thank all the lenders for her first loan, which she used to purchase an oven for her cakes and an ice cream machine. The loan has directly impacted her business in a positive way, generating more income than before. 

She is very happy to have had the help of her lenders. She is now looking to take another loan to purchase another oven. She has been so successful that demand for her cakes has increased, and one oven is not enough to keep up with customer demand. This second loan will help her to grow and improve the business. She wants to thank all of the lenders for their continued support.

loans.use: To purchase another oven

loans.name: Tegemeo Group

texts.en:
Hashimu, who is in his late 20s, is married with a kid who is still small. He has been selling secondhand shoes for three years now. He works from 10am to 4pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Hashimu's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase his stock of shoes and has paid back all his loans successfully. He used the profit to pay school fees, covered household expenses and saved some in his bank account. He will use this loan to buy shoes and starts selling second-hand clothes. He dreams of opening a shop where he can sell his products in one place instead of door to door.  

Hashimu will share this loan with his loan group "Tegemeo" which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy shoes and start selling second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 47 years old and lives in Dicoloc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married, with one son now at school age. 

Catherine is engaged in an agri-business activity, specifically, she has been doing rice production for 10 years already. She earns approximately PHP5,000 each month doing this type of business activity. Her husband also supports their family from his income as a carpenter. 

She has requested a loan to be used in paying the tuition fees and miscellaneous expenses for her son’s education. 

Catherine has been a member of PMPC for almost six years. In the future, Catherine hopes to expand her agri-business by engaging in a cacao production business.

loans.use: to pay the tuition fees and miscellaneous expenses

loans.name: Villamora

texts.en:
Villamora, 44 years old, is married and had six children. She has owned and operated a transportation transport service for many years to earn a living. She had supported the family's daily needs with this income. Her operator rented her tricycle daily, while her husband worked as a carpenter. 

She had repaid successfully her previous loan, used for purchasing vehicle accessories. 

She took a new loan recently to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.  

She wants to renovate her house for a safer and more comfortable living for her family.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman is 31 years old. He is married, and together with his spouse, has been blessed with two children. Suleiman runs a grocery store, a business he has done for the last four years, earning a monthly income of 35,000 KES (Kenyan shillings). 

He has requested his first loan with VisionFund Kenya of 15,000 KES, which he will use to add stock of sodas for resale. 

With the anticipated profits, Suleiman will be able to expand his business further as well as repay his loan. His hopes and dreams for the future are to have a stable business and happy family.

loans.use: to buy stock for his grocery store

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman. She has 3 children. She describes herself as honest and hardworking. 

She operates a retail business where she sells fruits and vegetables. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a suitable location. She describes her biggest business challenge to be poor means of transport and lack of capital. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of fruits and vegetables. Her business goal is to be financially stable within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy more stock of groceries.
